title: Large-Scale Language Learning Design Strategies Applying Cognitive Load Theory: Optimization of Text, Vocabulary, and Communication

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational grasp of language learning theories (grammar, vocabulary, reading comprehension) and instructional design concepts, along with basic understanding of Second Language Acquisition (SLA) theories
context.additional_context: Strengthens experimental design and analytical competencies for applying cognitive load theory in language education courses for working professionals (business conversation/document writing). Develops customized strategies considering text complexity and working memory limits to enhance learners' communication efficiency.

learning_goals: Distinguish and explain the three types of cognitive load (intrinsic, extraneous, germane), and analyze cognitive barriers occurring during language learning.

Apply cognitive load theory-based design principles to language learning materials (texts, dialogues, writing tasks) to revise and develop instructional materials considering learnersâ€™ working memory capacity.

In blended learning environments, propose two or more cognitive load management strategies tailored to learner characteristics (grammar level, vocabulary size, reading speed) (e.g., chunked presentation, enhanced visual support) and apply them to actual classes.
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
